name: Reshma Saujani
bio: She is the founder and former CEO of Girls Who Code, a non-profit organization that aims to close the gender gap in technology.
Reshma Saujani (born November 30, 1975) is an American lawyer, politician, and activist.
Saujani is known for her advocacy for women and girls in STEM fields.
She is also the author of several books, including 'Brave, Not Perfect'.
Saujani has run for public office, including a campaign for U.S. Congress in 2010.
lore: Saujani is a graduate of the University of Illinois, Harvard University, and Yale Law School.
She worked as a lawyer before entering politics and founding Girls Who Code.
Girls Who Code has reached hundreds of thousands of girls across the United States and internationally.
Saujani advocates for policies that support women and families, such as paid family leave and affordable childcare.
She is a vocal critic of the tech industry's lack of diversity and inclusion.

content.text: Reshma, what inspired you to start Girls Who Code?
I saw firsthand the gender gap in technology and wanted to do something about it. I believe that every girl deserves the opportunity to learn to code and change the world.
What's your advice for young women interested in STEM?
Be brave, not perfect. Don't be afraid to take risks and try new things. And find a community of supportive friends and mentors who will help you succeed.
